bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, January 2, 1948

div1.p: Hench wants to know if it would be possible for Carter's correspondences to be sent to him to review. He is anxious to learn more about Carter's place in the yellow fever story, and thus far has found little to document his role.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, January 2, 1948
div1.opener:
Y, F.
January 2, 1948
Mr. H. Carter Redd
1104 Travelers Building
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Mr. Redd:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly indeed for your kind letter of December 19.
I shall take your suggestion and write to Doctor Carter's son. I do hope
that you can find time in the not too distant future to go over the boxes
of letters stored in Ashland, Virginia. Are all these letters from Doctor
Carter?

I hope you won't misunderstand the following suggestion. If you
do not have time to go through these letters but would be willing to have
them expressed insured to me, I should be glad indeed to go over them. I
have done this on more than one occasion. The Lazear relatives found a
mass of correspondence in an attic. They didn't have time to go over the
letters very carefully. Many of the letters were personal. I only made
notes from those which concerned yellow fever. They were invaluable to
me. I would be delighted to do that in this case and would return to you
safely all the letters. (“Cross my heart and hope to die.”)

I am so anxious to give Doctor Carter his proper place in the
story of yellow fever and to date I have found very little besides the one
or two very important papers and some hearsay. I have not yet been able to
learn just how closely and how early in Reed's yellow fever work Doctor
Carter and his work were brought to Reed's or Lazear's attention.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
